My fianc√© just graduated from Stanford Business School, and naturally my first thought was: What's in it for me? I read through his courses for his last quarter, and decided to crash his class called ‚ÄúWinning Writing.‚Äù Taught by Glenn Kramon , the class offers ‚Äútechniques and practical exercises for writing better -- better memos, emails, and feedback for colleagues.‚Äù As someone who writes countless emails, gives constant feedback, and pitches ideas daily, I knew this could be game-changing. Since we can't all crash Stanford classes, here are the three techniques that will transform how you write starting today: Kill your adverbs: We know that you're ‚Äúcurrently‚Äù writing this email, because, well, it is the current time. We know that it‚Äôs unfortunate that the budget was cut, but we don‚Äôt need you to tell us it‚Äôs ‚Äúunfortunately been cut.‚Äù Doesn‚Äôt matter if you‚Äôre ‚Äúreally‚Äù excited about the new initiative. Being `excited` is enough. Next time you type out ‚Äúwe can absolutely do that,‚Äù try deleting the ‚Äúabsolutely.‚Äù Rethink how you give feedback: The framework for this is to say what you like (praise) and then what you would like (suggestions for improvement), not what you don't like. I'll use myself as an example (yes, I'm sometimes late to meetings - this is vulnerable, okay): ‚Ä¢ DON‚ÄôT DO THIS: ‚ÄúNatalie, you're often late to meetings. It‚Äôs unprofessional, and doesn‚Äôt bode well with clients.‚Äù ‚Ä¢ Instead, TRY THIS: ‚ÄúNatalie. You sparkle in meetings and clients love you -- when you're on time. Would you show up a couple minutes before the meeting starts to assure you‚Äôre ready and all your tech is working.‚Äù Lead with your headline: A powerful message has a Headline (10%), Example (80%), and Relevance (10%). If you‚Äôre speaking, on a micro-scale in meetings, or on stage giving a keynote, try to open with a clear statement. I tend to bury the point of what I‚Äôm saying beneath a pile of ‚Äúums,‚Äù ‚Äúlikes,‚Äù and ‚Äúthis is probably stupid but‚Ä¶‚Äù Say your main thought straight out of the gate! Your turn: Pick one technique and use it this week. Then tell me which one made the biggest difference. ‚ÄúDo not leave the airport. We need to get you out of there.‚Äù This was the text I received from my manager last Wednesday after I had touched down in Los Angeles. I flew to Los Angeles for a commercial shoot (that I was shocked was still happening), and kept turning off my news alerts and lying to myself that everything was going to be okay. As we got closer to landing, outside of my plane window, I could see smoke and flames. It was apocalyptic. Right as I touched down and got cell service, I received word from the crew that the Hollywood Hills fire had just started, and the shoot had to be cancelled. Within minutes my hotel was in an evacuation zone, and my team was looking for the first flight out because it wasn‚Äôt safe to be there. While this experience was absolutely nothing compared to the devastation happening across LA, I felt called to action to do something. It felt unfair that while I was able to book a flight home, back to safety, hundreds of people didn‚Äôt even have a place to call home anymore. As a California native, LA holds a special place in my heart, as I know it does for so many around me in the Bay Area. It sounds clich√©, but moments like these‚Äîwhen uncontrollable wildfires erupt and devastating losses occur‚Äîremind us that our jobs are far from the most important things about us. I called Annie and said we had to pause work. I posted on my story asking if people knew about any donation centers or initiatives happening in the Bay Area to provide relief to LA. Within hours, a fellow SF creator, Jessi Caparella , reached out to me to team up and try to make something happen. We reached out to Roadway Moving to get a 26ft truck to a parking lot in Emeryville, and Jessi and I posted on our Instagram stories informing people to show up with donations, if they had them, on Sunday. Within an hour, traffic was gridlocked down to the highway, we had enough donations to fill the truck, and we had to shut down the drive (a great problem to have!). Together, we gathered new and gently used items from the Bay Area, packed them up, and coordinated with the Roadway team to deliver them to a team on the ground in Los Angeles, currently set to receive them today. To say I was overwhelmed by the turnout would be an understatement. People got out of their cars, rolled their sleeves up, and helped for hours. I feel grateful for this community‚Äîthe people who went shopping for brand new toiletries, showed up, waited in line to give their donations, and got out of their cars to help. I felt love, strength, and support in every hug I received and every smile I saw. I may or may not have burst into tears when I got home from the drive‚Ä¶and then promptly crashed at 7 PM. I guess to add my LinkedIn ‚Äútakeaway‚Äù to this, if you feel called to act or help your community in any way, do it. It can easily get lost in the shuffle of the work grind, but don‚Äôt let it. Thank you to everyone who continues to care and show up for each other during difficult times!

Let‚Äôs say you want to propose a new project to your team. Or maybe you‚Äôre heading into your performance review and want to show up looking ~prepared~. Every company has their format, but as an ex-consultant, I‚Äôve spent quite some time building decks for client projects, proposals, and even my own performance reviews. If I‚Äôm ever trying to put thoughts together in my current job as a content creator, I‚Äôll first pull up blank slides (my teammate Annie V. has a love-hate relationship with my deck obsessionü•≤). I utilize slides for pitches to brands, advising strategies, internal performance reviews, training modules for my team, and post-mortems following partnerships. Here are four tips that I think make every deck better: 1. Identify the problem. Get to the point within the first two slides of your presentation in the form of a problem statement. Why should someone spend their precious time looking at this deck? If you‚Äôre proposing getting allocated more funds to support a team happy hour, the problem statement could be something witty like ‚ÄúWe do good work, but we don‚Äôt celebrate that enough.‚Äù Pro tip: keep this problem statement to one or two simple sentences. The more you elaborate on the problem, the trickier it becomes to solve. 2. Use icons. Wow‚Ä¶I‚Äôm SUCH a consultant. Icons make a boring slide interactive and easy to follow. 3. Provide data to substantiate your proposal. Why should your audience believe in your plan of action? Do you have examples from the past or case studies that you can reference? I recently pitched integrating a brand sponsorship into my Gen Z series. I built a slide that included statistics from both the series on my channels (link clicks, engagement, etc.) and Gen Z consumer behaviors as they related to the brand‚Äôs industry / product. 4. List your next steps. A proposal is not of value unless you‚Äôve provided actionable steps for all stakeholders. I always make next steps attributional by listing them in a 2-column table format (action item on the left, the person responsible on the right). Is this similar to how you organize your pitch decks? Elf took advantage of this familiarity and comfort, and linked it with their brand to boost positive affinity seamlessly. 2. Explicitly addressing the narrative: Good makeup is expensive, and although Elf Beauty is more affordable than most brands, consumers don‚Äôt like to sacrifice the quality of their glam. This statement is simple and evident in this commercial. When given one full minute to promote a product, many marketing teams make their best effort to pack in as many value propositions as possible. Although this approach can be effective in certain situations, I‚Äôd argue that diving deeper into one key message in an entertaining and thorough manner (like Elf did here) leaves the audience with an unmistakable next step to purchase the product if they resonate with the issue presented. 3. Story first, product second: Clear product placement doesn‚Äôt appear until the 43 second mark in this commercial. The Elf team was confident that by providing an engaging storyline first, viewers would stay engaged until the last quarter of the commercial, where they could then insert their product as a definite solution to the problem, and subtly push their desired messaging. A few weeks ago, Vaval Victor, m.s. of AdWeek wrote this super insightful article on how Gen Z views advertising, and how that could shift the way marketing teams approach their strategies. As a cusp Gen Z/millennial and brand marketer myself, this article deeply resonated with me. The fact of the matter is that Gen Z is turned away by blatant advertising, cares way more than brands think about their company values, and will more likely turn to other consumers for testimonials when deciding to purchase a product. This leaves marketing teams in a position to innovate yet again. Here are the tips this article gave for adjusting your team‚Äôs advertising approach to Gen Z consumer behaviors: 1. ‚ÄúTurn-off signals in ad copy are disruptive‚Äù: As an influencer who creates sponsored ads for a living, my main objective is keeping my audience engaged. My goal is to make the video feel like any of my other skits, because that‚Äôs what my followers love. As a brand, one way you can mirror this practice is by having a consistent ‚Äúhook‚Äù at the beginning of your video content. The hook shouldn‚Äôt address your product in any way, rather the problem your product is solving. For example, if you‚Äôre selling a water bottle, start off by asking your viewer if they know what proper hydration feels like. 2. ‚ÄúCustomer experiences are key for brand credibility‚Äù: Studies have shown that about 40% of Americans use TikTok as their search engine tool instead of Google. It‚Äôs crucial that your team monitors the overall sentiment of your brand on TikTok and other social platforms, as these platforms do have power to sway consumer behavior (source linked below). 3. ‚ÄúBrand values matter as much as the product‚Äù: Let‚Äôs say your company values teamwork and innovation. Great! Gen Z will be eager to hear a story about a time when your organization came together to solve a problem in a creative way. These stories should not just be congratulated internally in company all-hands meetings, but rather shared with the public. Proof of impact is likely to garner more positive brand affinity than a video displaying your product‚Äôs features. 4. ‚ÄúGreat creative is remembered‚Äù: Gen Z can sniff an advertisement from a mile away. Their time is precious, and with so much content at their hands, they will not be spending that time watching your ad unless it entertains them. Rather than strategizing promotional content through the lens of how to effectively get the key messages across, shift your attention to how to entertain your audience first, and then embed your product in the most organic way possible. If your company is working to target a Gen Z audience, I‚Äôd start with these four strategies. I‚Äôd love to hear some additional tips in the comments below!

When I spoke to Dell Technologies employees at SXSW earlier this year, a woman asked me how to deal with the awkwardness of being a manager to someone who is the same age as you. She mentioned feeling ‚Äúweird‚Äù telling someone she considers to be a friend about areas that they need to improve in. While I remember throwing together a sub-par answer at the moment, I‚Äôve taken a bit more time to think through my advice on this topic since being asked. I often speak on best practices for navigating the workplace under your boss and alongside your team. This past year, I‚Äôve also taken on the role of being a manager to my own team of similar-aged women to myself, while still feeling personally very ‚Äúearly‚Äù in my career. Take it from me: it can be a bit awkward providing face-to-face feedback with direct reports that are close to your age. For those of you in similar positions, here are three tips to make your next performance review with your DR a tad less difficult: Acknowledgement: As dumb as it sounds, acknowledging the awkwardness is often the best way to start these performance-based discussions with similar-aged direct reports. As the Queen of Self-Deprecation and telling bad jokes in tense moments, this comes quite naturally to me, but if it doesn‚Äôt for you, try starting the discussion with ‚Äúlook, I‚Äôm new to this too, so let‚Äôs work together on getting through the awkwardness.‚Äù Trust me, it lightens the mood. Two-way street: Create a level playing field from the start by acknowledging not only their positive attributes and growth, but also areas where you may be lacking in management. If you arrive at the review with nothing but a list of critical feedback and zero areas of potential self-improvement, I can almost guarantee that your employee will be less receptive to criticism and will lack motivation to make change. I always kick off my performance reviews with a slide on ‚ÄúThings I Suck At‚Äù to both provide a few laughs and open the floor for my employee to comment in a genuine way on ways I can manage better. Plus, with every negative critique in life, it hurts less if you say it first yourself ;) Future visibility: It‚Äôs important to always ask your employee about their long term aspirations and how you can support them more in achieving those dreams. Despite being the same age, there‚Äôs a reason you‚Äôre the one managing them! How can you show them that you can provide genuine value to their career? Can you introduce them to someone in the organization who can help them develop a certain skill? Can you allow them to shadow a project that piques their interest? It‚Äôs crucial for all employees to feel that they are on the path to success in their careers, and that their manager will support them in that, no matter what age they are. Best of luck, managers!

Providing ‚Äúsafe weeks‚Äù creates space and flexibility for your employees to get their work done in ways that work best for them. PSA: Balance looks different for everyone, and it doesn't need to be extreme. I keep seeing content that feels like your phone is screaming at you to be better at balance and being present in the moment...that you need to either cut social media off completely because it is ruining your life or never ever EVER work on PTO because you will regret it on your deathbed. Let me just disclaim that if you have been reading my content here you know that I am a HUGE advocate for shutting out social media/work when you need to spend time with family and friends doing what you love and what fills your cup. BUT...hot take.. some of this extreme advice to set strict boundaries may actually be causing you to feel even worse. What `overwhelms` each individual and takes away from the moment is completely subjective. For example, I know for me and my teammate, we love a quick Sunday email catch-up. And oftentimes, when people see me on my email on a Sunday or behind my laptop, they urge me to `enjoy my Sunday`, saying that `it will always be there tomorrow`. YES, it will be. YES, if you only get a few hours with your family and friends on Sunday you should NOT be doing work. BUT, what if you find yourself with¬†some extra free time and motivation to check your inbox, and that extra bit of work on a Sunday allows you to be more present to your roommates, spouse, children, coworkers, etc. later in the week? I'd argue that a healthy choice would be to go ahead and log on for a bit. Here is a trick I use when determining how best to utilize my time. Ask yourself `Does spending this amount of time on XYZ provide me with the ability to be present/recharged/excited for a longer period of time in the next few days or weeks, or does it take away more joy than it provides?` Simple, right? Maybe give it a go.
